text: so we're talking about side chain
compression in Ableton this is one of
the most basic techniques that you can
learn but it's very effective
essentially side chaining if You' never
heard of this before it's where we take
one signal it's audio it's usually a
kick drum or a snare drum and we route
that sound to a compressor on another
sound and that other sound is triggered
by the compressor and Ducks the sound
while our trigger sound plays so it ort
of cuts out a little space for it to be
so all we need to do is we need to grab
a compressor right now we have uh kick
drum sound and some cords they both
sound like this
[Music]
together but we need the kick drum to
push those cords out of the way so we're
going to we're going to use a compressor
for that and all we got to do is we got
to load in our compressor and then we
need to flip open this section right
here and hit side chain so the
compressor is going to ask us what
signal we want to route to the
compressor and we are going to choose
our kick just like that and when we play
it nothing's really happening right you
can see this gain reduction
meter it's barely moving right we don't
we need that to be going down a lot more
so we could bring our threshold down and
this is basically telling the compressor
to start working when it receive signal
above - 35.3
DB now we're starting to get somewhere
we'll bring up that ratio as well we're
going to turn down our attack the ratio
just tells the compressor how much
compression to apply we want to apply a
lot here you can even go up to infinite
if you
[Music]
want if you really want that aggressive
side chaining uh but just adjust all of
these to taste this is a very important
one too the release a lot of guys that I
would teach they would just leave it at
50 and they'd be like all right I'm good
but a lot of the time you want to click
over here and look at this graph view
this will give you a better visual
representation of what your side
chaining is
doing the higher the release the longer
it takes for that compressor to recover
and let that sound back in
[Music]
but another contributing factor is the
signal we have sending to the compressor
right we picked our kick but our kick
isn't just that first initial punch
which is really what we want to be
triggering this compressor so we're
going to turn on our EQ and what this is
going to do is it's going to filter the
signal that the compressor is picking up
so in this case a kick drum has it has
really high frequencies for the
transient but mostly low frequencies for
the tail and the body
so we probably don't need much of that
tail which is just base so we could
bring this up maybe like we'll bring it
up to like 400 Hertz
[Music]
almost now it looks really tight and
this could be what we're after but if
you're looking for that pumping action
you want to probably bring that release
back up
[Music]
and you could still adjust all the
parameters to taste this is really just
about what works best for your song but
that's how you get side chaining in
Ableton
